It is interesting to note here that in general there are two differen=
t users involved.
1) The technical user that issues the GET/POST/PUT/DELETE=
 request
2) The logical user that the resource is associated to.

These may=
 be the same or they may be different. F.x. it could be possible for an adm=
inistrator to view/modify a record that belongs to another use. Hence I wou=
ld not say that one can just use HTTP authentication here. Yes, one can use=
 HTTP authentication for security but not necessarily for getting the appli=
cable information. 

 
> If you have resources that only exist for that giv=
en user,
> I'd use your former approach /project/user/A/data because it
> e=
stablishes a dedicated URI space per user.

The problem here is that what d=
ata belongs to what user may be transient (or maybe just have create relati=
onship only to the user). F.x. if the user that the data belongs to leaves =
the company that owns the data, then the same resource might be the respons=
ibility of another user.
